loan.name: Vicenta

texts.en:
Vicenta H. is from the village of Tipolohon, Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 51 years old and is married with nine adult children.
Vicenta owns and operates a business planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale at the same time, she also engaged into selling variety of products like canned goods, coffee, soft drinks and other primary products. She has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month.She's into sari sari store as another source of her income to provide the needs of the family since farming is seasonal in the Philippines.
In 2009, Vicenta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise.
Vicenta is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to rent land to raise additional crops. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loan.name: Nsasa Development Group-Mukono

texts.en: L. Derrick, 62, began his dairy farming business in Nsasa-Mukono with much motivation plus help from friends and family. This smile-up-his-sleeve gentleman has a sparky sense of humor, which has struck a chord with many of his customers. His milk is in high favor with many people in his locality Derrick belongs to Nsasa development group in Mukono. He is a happily married man with nine children. Only one of his children is in school as the majority of his children have chosen to follow him into business. Derrick makes as much as 49,000 UGX per week. With this loan he is anticipating buying cattle feed. He was a government employee before venturing into business, and is a very hardworking and determined man.

loan.use: To purchase more cattle feed

loan.name: Vorn

texts.en: Mr. Vorn P. is 60 years old and his wife, Mrs. Yorn Yang, is 48 years old. They have been married since 1991 and have two children â€“ a son and a daughter, both of whom are garment factory workers. The family lives in a Phnom Penh suburb. Vorn has been a rice farmer for 30 years. His wife sells Akor (a kind of small cupcake, made of sticky rice, coconut cream and sugar cooked in steam) in her village and the nearby village. Vorn is requesting his first loan of $900 to purchase a motorbike for commuting and a cow to raise and use on his farm.

loan.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting and a cow to raise

loan.name: Khanga Group

texts.en:
Havinitishi N., who is in her middle thirties, is married with two sons and two daughters. She has been running a grocery business selling beer, soda and water for two years. She works from 4 p.m. to 12 p.m. and is able to earn a monthly profit of about $92.
This will be Havinitishiâ€™s 3rd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She has successfully paid back her previous loans which she used to increase her stock and bought empty beer crates and chairs.
Havinitishi hopes for this loan so that she can buy a TV and also start selling spirits. Her dream is to buy a car that she can use to carry her grocery products.
Havinitishi will share this loan with her loan group, Khanga, which totals fifteen members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back the loan.
In the photo, Havinitishi is at the back, second from the right.

loan.use: To buy a TV and start selling spirits

loan.name: Nyamutaba 1 Twimutsyane, Ntungamo Group

texts.en:
B. Bernard is a determined and hardworking married father of eight children. He has been operating a local-brew sales business for over twenty-three years in Nyamutaba Trading centre, Ntungamo.
Bernard says he began his business from the small savings he got from group savings that he made in the past with friends. This helped him to begin his first sales of the local brew commonly known as waragi here in Uganda.
Bernard describes his customers as good ones who give him a ready market for his local brew. He sells to bar owners in the area, earning him 320,000 Ugandan shillings.
Bernard is currently faced with the big challenge of finding transport as he looks at ways of supplying an expanded market. Therefore, his motive in requesting this loan is to use it to assist in the purchase of transportation means like a motorcycle or pickup truck for his business so as to improve his sales revenue.

loan.use: To contribute towards the purchase of a vehicle for his business

loan.name: Leoncio

texts.en:
Leoncio D. is from the village of Unidos, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. He is 54 years old and is married with two school-aged children. Leoncio owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling daily-use products such as vinegar, cooking oil, soy sauce, shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for over ten years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Leoncio joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. Leoncio is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be his third from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement his family's income. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loan.name: Shally

texts.en:
Shally D. is from the village of Nacional, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years old and is married with two school-aged children. Shally owns and operates a business selling religious items, primarily selling incense and candles to tourists and to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month. In 2005, Shally joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Shally is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional religious items and materials. This loan will be her eighth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase additional religious items and materials

loan.name: Gemma

texts.en: Gemma T. is from the village of Linganngaoo, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 41 years old and is married with three school-aged children. Gemma owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Gemma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase piglets to raise and sell. Gemma is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies. This loan will be her 4th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. loan.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta E. is from the village of Magsaysay, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 44 years old and is married with five adult children. Julieta owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, tuba (coconut wine), canned goods, noodles, toothpaste and other items in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 9,200 PHP a month. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. Julieta is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her fifth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. loan.name: Oliva

texts.en:
Oliva is 34 years old and is married with three children. She owns a restaurant where she sells tea as well as some pastries. She has been in this business for about five years and her business hours are from the morning hours until late in the evening.
Although Oliva has been in this business for about five years, her capital is still too low to expand her business meaningfully. To solve this problem, she is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a. With the use of this loan, she will hopefully earn more profits which, in turn, will be used for better reinvestment in the future.

loan.use: To invest in expanding her business

loan.name: Marife

texts.en:
Marife D. lives in the village of Hinaplanan, Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 38 years old, married and has two school-aged children. She makes a living running a specialized store where she buys and sells bananas. Marife has been in this line of work for more than eight years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.
In 2008, Marife joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid five previous loans from HSPFI and is applying for a new one, for 5,000 PHP, to buy additional items to sell to her customers. She plans to use the additional income made possible by this loan to continue expanding her business.
About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loan.name: Farida

texts.en:
Farida lives in a small city called Riwind, which is located near Lahore and famous for its dairy and farming industries. She is 45 years old and has lived in this area for the last 22 years. She is married to M. H., who is 53 years old and is in the business of selling rice and wheat.
Farida is a housewife who also owns a buffalo and sells its milk to people who live in her community. She has been in this line of work for the last eight years.
Farida and her husband have seven children, four sons and three daughters, Only four are in school, in part because her older children had to leave school at an early age to support the family financially. Her oldest son is a rickshaw driver and one of her younger sons works in a small hotel in Lahore, where he lives during the work week. Her oldest daughter does embroidery work, taking orders from clients who live nearby.
Farida has applied for a loan from Asasah to expand her milk-selling business. She plans to use the money to buy another buffalo, which will give her more milk to sell to her clients. She has taken out five previous loans from Asasah and repaid each on time She has also never missed a meeting called by our organization.

loan.use: To buy a buffalo in order to sell its milk in local markets

loan.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is 30 years old and is married with 3 children who are 5, 7 and 9 years old. Judith is well-known in the business of selling secondhand clothes in Nyabugogo market. She has been in this business for about ten years and the business hours are from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.
Judith needs a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to purchase different styles of secondhand clothes which will hopefully increase her sales as well as her profits. With these profits, she will keep reinvesting in the same business for better financial stability in the future. In addition to that, she will be able to continue taking care of her children.

loan.use: To purchase diffferent styles of clothes to sell

loan.name: Arlyn

texts.en:
Arlyn L. lives in the village of Malagana, Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 39 years old, married and has six school-aged children. She makes a living by buying and selling bananas. She has been in this line of work for more than five years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.
In 2009, Arlyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid two previous loans from HSPFI and is applying for a new one, for 6,000 PHP, to expand her business.
About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loan.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 25-year-old single man living with his 2 parents. He is an experienced furniture painter with almost 8 years in the business. Heâ€™s a new business owner, and has owned his shop since 2009. He works upon request of his customers and also in collaboration with some galleries. He has already received his first kiva loan and heâ€™s very thankful for the results.
This borrower is the main provider for with parents. His story illustrates the day-to-day challenges many people are facing in trying to take care of household expenses, sick and aging family members while at the same time running a business. Today, he is asking for a loan of $2000 to purchase new tools for his business. In the future, he would like to expand his business and open his own gallery shop.

loan.use: To purchase new tools

loan.name: Danilo

texts.en:
Danilo Y. lives in the village of Gen. Balao, Solana, Cagayan. He is 30 years old, married and has three school-aged children. He makes a living by raising livestock, principally pigs, which he fattens before selling. He has been in this line of work for more than two years and earns about 3,500 PHP each time he sells an animal.
Earlier this year, Danilo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his life and ability to engage in business. He is applying for his first loan, for 4,000 PHP, to buy baby livestock to raise and sell when they are grown. He plans to use the additional revenue generated by this loan to supplement his family's income.
About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to buy young livestock to raise and sell in the future

loan.name: Seng

texts.en: Mrs. Seng K. is 39 years old and lives in Phnom Penh province, where she has owns a small house in which she lives with her family. She works for a milk company and earns a salary of about $100 a month. Her husband works with her at the same location. The couple has a young child who is enrolled in school. Seng K.'s house is old and in need of repairs. She is applying for a $500 loan from Kivaâ€™s field partner HKL to improve and repair her house.

loan.use: To improve and repair her house

loan.name: Therese

texts.en:
Therese is 46 years old and married with four children. Therese makes a living by selling different styles of clothes. The business hours are from 8 am to 5 pm every day. She has been in this business for about 15 years.
Therese needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a. With this loan, Therese will hopefully increase her sales as well as profits. These profits will allow her to keep reinvesting for better financial stability in the future. In addition, she will start saving for a better future for her family.

loan.use: To buy different styles of clothes for sale

loan.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma L., from the village of General Balao, Solana, Cagayan, is 41 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Gemma owns and operates a business venture raising pigs for breeding. Engaged in her business for over 10 years, she earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Gemma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan from ASKI, she is now requesting a new loan, her second, of 5000 PHP to open another business. Gemma plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loan.name: Marcelina

texts.en:
Marcelina C. is from the village of General Balao, Solana, Cagayan. She is 34 years old. Marcelina is married and has five infant children. Marcelina owns and operates a livestock business. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Marcelina has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4000 Philippine pesos (PHP) whenever she sells one of her grown animals.
In 2009, Marcelina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Marcelina has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. Marcelina is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Marcelina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.
About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisher-folk and small entrepreneurs.

loan.name: El

texts.en: Mrs. El S. is a long-time businesswoman and a low-income person. She has been operating a beauty business since early 2009. In the local market, she owns a kiosk where she sells different kinds of miscellaneous materials. She sells items such as perfumes, beauty products, and some costume jewelry to people who come to buy anything in the market. El S. was married but divorced her husband when her kids were very young. She now has two grown children who are no longer in school and are employed (a daughter sews clothes in factory and a son is a goldsmith). In order to earn extra profits and to make the business more successful, El S. will be using the loan she requested to accumulate a larger quantity of her inventory items.

loan.use: expanding store inventory

loan.name: Chantal

texts.en:
Chantal is 46 years old and married with three children. Chantal is well known in her business selling different styles of clothes. This is her 10th successful year in the business. Her business hours are from 9 am to 5 pm every day.
Although Chantal has been in business for a long time, her capital is still too low to expand meaningfully. To end this, she needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a. With this loan, Chantal will purchase additional styles of clothes to sell which in turn will increase her customers as well as profits. Apart from that, she really hopes that the lifestyle of her family will improve and she will start saving for better financial stability in the future.

loan.name: Savy

texts.en:
Mrs. Savy U., 47, and her husband, Mr. Sam-oeun Chem, 45, have been married since 1993 and have two children, a son and daughter, both students. They live on an island on the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Savy has been a silk weaver for a year, selling her finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh market. She is now requesting a loan of 500 USD to purchase weaving materials for her business and to pay school fees for her son.

loan.use: To buy weaving materials for her business and pay school fees for her son.

loan.name: Sou

texts.en: Mrs. Sou K. is a 58-year-old married woman who sells grocery items out of her home. She has had twenty years' experience and earns approximately of $3 per day. Her husband (shown in the picture) buys clothes that are less than export quality from garment industries to resell in his community for a profit. This has been very profitable for family, and Sou K. now needs a loan so her husband can increase his working capital. The couple has nine children, five of whom are married.

loan.use: To increase the working capital of the clothing business.

loan.name: Cirila

texts.en:
Cirila A. is from the village of Bago. She is 56 years old and married with three adult children. To make a living, Cirila owns a general store. She has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 4,800 PHP a month.
In 2009, Cirila joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC and is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Cirila from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business.
About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loan.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine B. is from the village of Barangay Lactawan, a part of the municipality of Solano in Nueva Vizcaya province of the Luzon islands. She is 47 years old, married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Josephine owns a retail store from which she sells home products such as glasses and watches to the local community. Josephine has been in business for over eight years and earns approximately 6500 PHP a month.

In 2006, Josephine joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. Josephine successfully repaid her previous loan of 19,000 PHP from ASKI which she used to purchase additional products to sell. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, her tenth loan, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her line of products. She plans to use all additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loan.name: Delegpuntsag

texts.en:
Mr Delegpuntsag is 32 years old, married, and has two children, Barsbayar, 12 and Barsbold, 3, in secondary school and kindergarten respectively. His family used to live in Gobi-Altai aimag (Province) of Mongolia, which is located 1000 kilometers south-west of the capital city of Mongolia. In 2008 they decided to move to Darkhan, the second largest city of Mongolia, in search of a better life. As soon as they moved there, Delegpuntsag bought a small car and started running a taxi business, which has been quite successful, while his wife works as a salesperson in a local grocery store.

Last year they bought a plot of land with a small wooden house on it. Delegpuntsag, an energetic and enthusiastic person, says, â€œI would like to be financially able to provide a good education and better life for my children." With the loan that he is requesting, he is planning to replace his car by buying a second hand vehicle in better condition.
