loan.name: Rose

texts.fr:
Madame ROSE G. est une femme de 82 ans. Elle est mariÃ©e et mÃ¨re de 06 enfants majeurs. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de NGASCOP depuis son inauguration il y a de cela 14 ans. Elle a 28 fois de suite reÃ§u de crÃ©dit et a toujours remboursÃ© sans difficultÃ©.
Elle est Ã©leveuse de porcs. A cause de son Ã¢ge avancÃ©, elle est aidÃ©e par ses enfants pour bien mener cette activitÃ© qu'elle pratique depuis plus de 20 ans
Avec son crÃ©dit elle va acheter 30 pourceaux Ã raison de 15.000 francs cfa, et de la nourriture pour leurs alimentation.
Son objectif est de prendre en charge ses besoins personnels, renforcer son Ã©pargne et participer Ã la prise en charge financiÃ¨re de la famille.
texts.en:
Rose G. is an 82 year old woman. She is married and she is the mother of 6 grown children. She has been a member of the Community Bank NGASCOP (Kiva field Partner) since its inception 14 years ago. She has attained 28 past loans and she always repaid the funds without any trouble. She is a pig farmer. Because she is an elderly person she gets help from her children in running the business, one that she has had for more than 20 years. With the help of this loan she will purchase 30 piglets at 15 francs and she will also purchase feed for them. Her goal is to be able to provide for her own needs, to save money, and contribute to the family's finances.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To purchase 30 piglets.

loan.name: Lafia Group

texts.fr: Les quatre membres du groupe Lafia sont 3 femmes mariÃ©es et 1 veuve qui ont une moyenne dâ€™Ã¢ge de 35 ans, 4 enfants et qui vivent dans des familles polygames Ã KAMALEN SIRAKORO un des villages de la commune de Sikasso, (3Ã¨me rÃ©gion administrative du Mali). Elles collaborent avec lâ€™institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientÃ¨le et sont Ã leur treiziÃ¨me prÃªt. Les prÃªts passÃ©s se sont tous bien dÃ©nouÃ©s. Elles font la vente dâ€™articles divers tels la pomme de terre, les tasses aluminium, les habillements avec Kadiatou Vieux T.. Avec son nouveau prÃªt, elle compte acheter, 20 piÃ¨ces de pagnes et tissus. Elle sâ€™approvisionne au marchÃ© de Sikasso auprÃ¨s des grossistes. Elle vend au marchÃ© de KAMALEN SIRAKORO et Ã domicile, au comptant, en dÃ©tail et souvent Ã crÃ©dit Ã une clientÃ¨le composÃ©e dâ€™hommes et de femmes. Elle envisage rÃ©aliser un bÃ©nÃ©fice mensuel de 35.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisÃ©e pour lâ€™Ã©pargne et les besoins de la famille, lâ€™autre partie sera investie dans les activitÃ©s. Elle ambitionne avoir plus de capitaux pour mieux satisfaire sa clientÃ¨le et pouvoir sâ€™acheter des articles pour le trousseau de mariage de sa premiÃ¨re fille.
texts.en:
Of the four members of the Lafia group 3 are married women and one is a widow. The average age is 35 and they have four children each. The live in polygamous families in Kamalen Sirakoro, one of the villages of the Sikasso commune (the third administrative region of Mali). They all work with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner) in order to be able to meet the clients' demands. This is their third loan. The past loans have all been repaid in full. They sell various merchandise items, such as potatoes, aluminium cups, and clothing with Kadiatou Vieux T.. With this loan she will purchase 20 wraps and pieces of fabric. She carries out her purchases from wholesalers in the Sikasso market. She sells her items in the Kamalen Sirakoro market and from her home. She finalizes her sales in cash and often in credit, selling to a clientele made up of both men and women. She plans on seeing monthly earnings of 35.500 francs, a part of which will be put away into savings and part will be used to fill the family's needs. She will also reinvest some earnings back into the business. Her ambitions are to have greater capital funds to be able to meet her clients' demands. She also hopes to purchase wedding items for her eldest daughterâ€™s marriage.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To purchase clothing.

loan.name: Madeleine

texts.fr:
Madame Madeleine T., une femme de 43 ans. Elle est mariÃ©e et mÃ¨re 06 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de NGASCOP depuis 14 ans. Elle a 28 fois de suite reÃ§u de crÃ©dit et a toujours remboursÃ© dans les dÃ©lais.
Elle fait de l'embouche porcine. Elle mÃ¨ne cette activitÃ© depuis son adhÃ©sion dans le Banc Villageois.
Avec son nouveau crÃ©dit elle va acheter 25 porcs qu'elle va emboucher et revendre soit sur pied, soit aprÃ¨s abattage.
Son objectif est de soutenir son mari dans la prise en charge financiÃ¨re de la famille tout en renforÃ§ant son niveau d'Ã©pargne.
texts.en:
Mrs. Madeleine T. is a 43 year old woman. She is married and she has 6 children. She has been a member of the community bank NGASCOP (Kiva Field Partner) for the past 14 years. She has received 28 past loans and she has always repaid her loan on time. She is a pig farmer. She has been running this business ever since she joined the community bank. With this loan she will purchase 25 piglets for her to raise and later resell. Her goal is to contribute with her husband towards the family's finances and to contribute to their savings.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To purchase 25 piglets.

loan.name: Oyun

texts.en:
Oyun R., age 46, lives with her husband and three children in a Ger, traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her oldest daughter attends a university while her youngest son attends a secondary school. Her older son, Ganbaatar, works as a private businessman. Her husband runs a transportation business in his town to supplement his family's income.
Oyun operates a fruit retail business at a stall in Narantuul, Ulaanbaatar's biggest market. Her business earnings have enabled her to improve her family's quality of living. She is a well organized and skillful businesswoman. She says, "I want to expand my business operation as well as provide a high level, good education to my children". Oyun is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to buy more fruit to increase her working capital.

loan.use: To buy more fruit.

loan.name: Dil

texts.en: Dil M. is 25 years old and has been selling a fresh fish in the local busy market for more than nine years. She sells fish that she buys from her wholesale supplier and from other fishermen. She is married to Hab Sakin, 23, who works as a furniture producer. The couple has given birth to a young child who is enrolled in the primary school. Presently, Dil M.â€˜s business has faltered due to insufficient financial capital. In view of that, Dil M. has applied for her first loan, to increase her capital.

loan.use: To increase her capital.

loan.name: Oyundalai

texts.en:
Oyundalai J. is 46 years old and lives with her husband and three daughters in the Huvsgul province of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her oldest two daughters, aged 19 and 18, are university students while her youngest daughter, age 12, attends a local secondary school.
Oyundalai operates a electron products repair service center, with help of her husband. She began her business next to a grocery shop in 2003. Since then, she has built a stable operation of repairing and performing maintenance on the local peopleâ€™s electron products. She purchases her raw materials from Erlian, China's border city. Her business is in good spot in the area and she has become popular amongst her customers. They business earnings are the only source of family income. She has used her earnings to pay for her children's tuition fees and on household consumption. Oyundalai is a very modest and hardworking person and is requesting a 3,100,000 MNT loan in order to purchase materials and tools for her repairing center.

loan.use: To purchase materials and tools.

loan.name: Saruul

texts.en:
Saruul T. is 47 years old and lives with her husband and two of her two sons in a Ger, traditional nomadic housing tent, in the Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. Her oldest son, 20, attends university while her husband and younger son are currently unemployed and stay at home.
Saruul operates a meat trade business her town, selling various kinds of meat. She began her business in 1998, and has built a stable operation. In the future, she plans to grow her business. Saruul is a friendly and open-minded person and says, "All I want is to provide my children with a good education". She is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan so that she can increase her working capital for her meat trading business.

loan.use: To purchase more meat.

loan.name: Kulziga

texts.en:
Kulziga H., 46 years old, lives with her husband and five children in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in the Bayan-Ulgiy province of western Mongolia. Her younger two children, aged 17 and 10, both attend a local secondary school, while her husband works as a guard in a kindergarten. Kulziga sells consumer goods at the local market. She also began a small cafe business in 1994 at Turlik market but still has not built a sustainable operation yet.
Kulziga purchases her products from the local wholesale stores, and her son helps her business during winter months. The business profits have enabled her to pay her children's tuition fees. Kulziga, a hardworking and honest person, says, " I want to save more money so that I can establish a new and bigger shop and pay my children's university tuition fees." She is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan both to purchase more goods at wholesale prices and to help pay for her oldest son's wedding.

loan.use: To purchase more goods at wholesale price

loan.name: Rafat

texts.en:
Rafat S. is dedicated to agricultural work and cattle breeding, which is his family's only income. In his family, he has his wife and 2 children. He has been dedicated to this business for several years and, over time, he has gained experience in cultivating crops.
Today, Rafat has come to AqroInvest Credit Union with the proposition of obtaining a loan to purchase one baby calf and seeds and fertilizer for planting. It is necessary to point out that in order to carry out the first planting you need to purchase the supplies. It is for this reason that Rafat is confident that his loan request will be successfully granted and he will achieve his objective of having a good harvest to improve his economic situation.

loan.use: To purchase one baby calf and seeds and fertilizer for planting.

loan.name: Lhagva

texts.en:
Lhagva D. lives with her husband and four children in Hentiy province of Mongolia. She and her family all live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her two oldest sons, Munhbaatar and Tumurbaatar, both have work in different places, while her younger daughter, Nandintsetseg attends university and the youngest daughter, Tsolmonpurev, studies at a local high school. Her husband is retired and stays at home.
Lhagva supports the entire family by operating a clothes making business. She repairs, and produces a variety of clothing items for her customers at a small rented workspace. She started her sewing business in 1973 by herself. Since then, she has gained many years of work experience and has built a stable operation. Today she owns 3 different kinds of sewing machines and tools that help her to design and sew the traditional Mongolian clothes. Her daily business income is around 20,000-22,000 MNT. From additional service and clothes repair, her monthly average income is approximately 900,000-1,200,000 MNT. In the future, she hopes to have her own house.
Lhagva is a very helpful and kind person and says, "I have been sewing traditional clothes for my entire life. Nowadays, I increased my production line and produce clothing and other home items according to my customer's specification. By sewing clothes, I can raise my children well, and so I am very proud of being a seamstress". She is requesting a 1,900,000 MNT loan in order to purchase fabrics and materials to make school uniforms.

loan.use: To purchase fabrics and materials.

loan.name: Nizami

texts.en:
The livestock business is one that requires much effort for the simple reasons that it requires sun exposure, the physical exertion of moving animals from one place to another, as well as the work it takes to tend to various crops. Nizami S., has dedicated himself, for already ten years, to cattle raising which supports his humble family who so rely on him. His monthly income is about 200-300 AZN. He is married and has four children.
Currently, Nizami has turned to AqroInvest CUI for a loan of 900 AZN to purchase calves so that he can raise and one milking cow of a specific type: â€œDamazâ€.

loan.use: To purchase one milking cow and one calf.

loan.name: Kamala

texts.en: Kamala H. is 44 years old. She is married and has three children. Since she has lived with her husband, she has worked in the business of buying and selling cattle. She walks through the farms and several settlements to buy cattle at the lowest price to be able to increase her profits. She currently has two cows and two calves. Her monthly income is about 180-220 AZN. Now, Kamala wants to expand her business and, as her children are grown up, she thinks that she will be able to look after more cattle with their help. So she is asking for 1000 AZN in order to purchase cattle and some sheep. Kamala expresses her gratitude to everyone supporting her and promises to repay the loan on time.

loan.use: To purchase cattle and six sheep.

loan.name: Lhagvajav

texts.en:
Lhagvajav H. is 51 years old and lives with her husband and one child in Huvsgul province of Mongolia. Her husband is currently unemployed. Her child is university student. She and her family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. She operates a meat trading business in her town, and provides a variety of meats for her customers.
Lhagvajav started her meat trading business in 2000 at a local market named Baigal - Eej, and has gained much business experience over the years. She is a very open-minded and laborious person. Lhagvajav plans to use her business earnings to improve her family's financial situation and to pay her children's tuition fees. She is requesting a 750,000 MNT loan to buy more meat to expand her working capital.

loan.use: To buy more meat.

loan.name: Ilyas

texts.en:
The business activity from which Ilyas A. makes a living is the breeding of livestock. He started this business 9 years ago with a small number of livestock. As his business has developed, he has acquired greater quantities of animals for their eventual sale and he has gained from their derivatives.
According to Ilyas, he works very hard so that he can take care of his children and his profit is 350-500 AZN. For that reason, he is always looking for a way to improve his family's living conditions. Currently, he needs a loan of 1000 AZN in order to purchase more cattle to later resell, after breeding them. This will allow him to fully meet the needs of his family.

loan.use: To purchase three cattle.

loan.name: Munhzaya

texts.en:
Munhzaya B. is 36 years old and lives with her two children in the Hentiy province of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in a rented yard. Her oldest son attends a university while her younger daughter attends a local high school.
Munhzaya supports the entire family by operating a clothes making business. She organizes her business very accurately. She has been operating her business since 2000 at a rented workplace. She owns a sewing machine and designs and sews the clothing according to her own tastes. Her daily average income is around 10,000-18,000 MNT and her monthly average income is approximately 400,000-500,000 MNT. She plans to have her own yard in the near future. She likes to sew clothes and it has become her hobby, as well as her profession. Munhzaya is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan in order to purchase a fabrics and materials to make various kind of uniforms.

loan.use: To purchase a fabrics, materials.

loan.name: Moussa

texts.fr: Monsieur MOUSSA T. est mariÃ© Ã une femmes et est pÃ¨re de 3 enfants. Il est nÃ© Ã LOULOUNI le 04/07/1978 dans la dite sous prÃ©fecture, 3eme rÃ©gion administrative du Mali (SIKASSO). Il vit Ã Loulouni dans une famille monogame. Il fait de la menuiserie mÃ©tallique avec la confection et rÃ©paration (de portes, fenÃªtres, chaises...) depuis maintenant 8 ans. Il fait ses prestations avec assez de rÃ©ussite compte tenu de son expÃ©rience Ã la matiÃ¨re. Il est Ã sa premiÃ¨re collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso et compte lâ€™utiliser pour acheter, des matÃ©riaux de premiÃ¨res nÃ©cessitÃ©s pour le bon dÃ©roulement de ses activitÃ©s. Il confectionne les portes, fenÃªtres...sur commande et ses prestations (rÃ©parations) au comptant Ã une clientÃ¨le composÃ©e dâ€™hommes et de femmes. Il espÃ¨re pouvoir Ã©conomiser mensuellement 40.000FCFA qui sera utilisÃ© pour payer la location de lâ€™atelier en plus des apprentis et lâ€™autre partie sera mise en Ã©pargne.
texts.en:
Mr. Moussa T. is married and he is the father of 3 children. He was born in Loulouni, Sikasso (third administrative region in Mali) on 4-07-1978. He lives in Loulouni in a monogamous family. He has worked as a joiner for the past 8 years, making and repairing metallic items such as doors, windows, and chairs. His business is quite successful given his experience in the field. This will be the first time he has approached Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner) for a loan. He hopes to use it to purchase essential materials for his business. He makes doors and windows, taking orders for new items, and he carries out repairs. His finalizes his transactions in cash only and he caters to a clientele made up of men and women. He hopes to earn 40.000 francs every month and it will be used to pay his store's lease, to hire on more apprentices, and a part will be put away in savings.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To purchase working materials.

loan.name: Rashad

texts.en: Rashad A. has a successful business selling food items. He started his business about 2 years ago, as an additional source of income. His primarily business is livestock breeding. Rashad purchases products, at very low prices, and then resells at a profit. Because he sells in bulk, he deals with a high inventory turnover rate. He has requested a loan of 1000 AZN to increase his business capital. This loan will give him the ability to purchase more products to sell, enabling him to increase his profits and to continue operating a profitable business. Rashad is going to use his loan also to purchase one cow.

loan.use: To purchase more products to sell and one cow.

loan.name: Naranjargal

texts.en:
Naranjargal A. is 36 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Tuv province of central Mongolia. She lives together with her family in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in her parents' yard. Her daughter, Uranchimeg, studies at high school in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city, while her son, Temuujin, attends a local kindergarten.
Naranjargal manages a shoe-making business in her town with help of her husband. She graduated Mongolian National University as a teacher. She started her business in 1997 and has built a sustainable operation. Her family's standard of living has improved greatly after operating the shoe-making business. Over the years of successful operation, her business has grown fast and she owns all the tools and equipment which are used in making shoes.
She and her husband work together, and plus she hired one worker. For the future, they plan to expand their business by increasing production capacity and to have their own shoe shop. She says "I work very hard to expand my business and also I teach my shoe-making skills to two handicapped children. In the future, I plan to establish a big shoe-making factory and open my own shop."
She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase a large amount of materials used in making traditional shoes.

loan.use: purchasing materials for fabricating shoes

loan.name: Marina

texts.en: Marina M. is a hard-working widow who has one child. For the past two years, Marina has dedicated herself to selling different kinds of home products. She started her business when her husband passed away and she wasnâ€™t able to feed her child. She likes what she sells and has developed a stable business. She makes about 250-300 AZN profit a month, but 30% of that goes to rent. Marina hopes that one day she will be able to build her own shop. Marina is now requesting a loan of 1000 AZN to help purchase new products to sell. This is important for her family's well-being.

loan.use: To purchase new products to sell

loan.name: Sabaly Group

texts.fr: Les quatre membres du groupe Sabaly, 3 femmes mariÃ©es et une veuve, avec une moyenne dâ€™Ã¢ge de 42 ans et 5 enfants vivent dans des familles polygames Ã KAMALEN SIRAKORO, un des villages de la commune de Sikasso, (3Ã¨me rÃ©gion administrative du Mali). Elles collaborent avec lâ€™institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientÃ¨le et sont Ã leur onziÃ¨me prÃªt. Les prÃªts passÃ©s se sont tous bien dÃ©nouÃ©s. Elles font entre autre la vente de charbons de bois, de condiments alimentaires et des chaussures en plastique avec Djata T.. Avec son nouveau prÃªt, elle compte acheter 12 douzaines de paires de chaussures en plastique. Elle sâ€™approvisionne au marchÃ© de Sikasso ville. Elle vend au marchÃ© de KAMALEN SIRAKORO, de faÃ§on ambulante et Ã domicile, au comptant et souvent Ã crÃ©dit Ã une clientÃ¨le composÃ©e dâ€™hommes et de femmes. Elle envisage rÃ©aliser un bÃ©nÃ©fice mensuel de 35.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisÃ©e pour lâ€™Ã©pargne et les besoins de la famille, lâ€™autre partie sera investie dans les activitÃ©s. Elle ambitionne avoir un prÃªt plus consistant pour mieux satisfaire sa clientÃ¨le et devenir grossiste Ã KAMALEN SIRAKORO
texts.en:
Of the four members of the group named Sabaly 3 are married women and one is a widow. They have an average age of 42 and they have 5 children each, living in polygamous families in Kamalen Sirakoro, a village of the Sikasso commune in the third administrative region of Mali. They are members of the microfinance instutution Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner) with the goal of meeting client demand. This will be their eleventh loan and their past loans have all been successfully repaid. Among other activities they sell wood coal, condiments, and plastic shoes with Djata T.. With this loan she will purchase 12 dozens of plastic shoes. She carries out her purchases in the Sikasso village market. She makes her sales in the market of Kamalen Sirakoro, while travelling, and from her home. She finalizes her sales in cash and often on credit. She sells to a clientele made up of both men and women. She foreseees earning 35.500 francs monthly, of which a part will be put away in savings and a part will be used to fill the family's needs. A part of these earnings will be reinvested back into the business. Her ambitions are to have a source of credit to better satisfy her clientele and to become a wholesaler in Kamalen Sirakoro.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To purchase plastic shoes.

loan.name: Ilqar

texts.en: Ilqar Q. is 42 years old, married, and has two children. His main work consists of breeding cattle. This very profitable activity enables him to provide for the needs of his family. His monthly income is 250-300 AZN. A very ambitious man, Ilqar would like to buy more cattle and build a barn to house them in order to ensure their safety. Due to a lack of finances, Ilqar is asking for a loan of 1000 AZN to purchase more cattle.

loan.use: To purchase cattle

loan.name: Khanish

texts.en:
Khanish K. is 58 years old and the father of three children. His wife is a housekeeper. In order to earn a living, Khanish owns a field for growing watermelon, grapes, and other seasonal fruits and vegetables. His monthly income is about 300-400 AZN.
On his farm, Khanish cannot do any planting because he does not have enough money for seeds and fertilizer. In order to purchase these items, he decided to ask for a loan of 500 AZN. Khanish counts on this planting opportunity to obtain a better yield, which will help him improve the living conditions of his family. He hopes one day to build his own shop next to his house and sell his harvest there.

loan.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizer

loan.name: Mougnoun Group

texts.fr: Le groupe Mougnoun est constituÃ© de femmes mariÃ©es qui ont une moyenne dâ€™Ã¢ge de 37 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames Ã KAMALEN SIRAKORO un des villages de la commune de Sikasso, (3Ã¨me rÃ©gion administrative du Mali). Elles collaborent avec lâ€™institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientÃ¨le et sont Ã leur cinquiÃ¨me prÃªt. Les prÃªts passÃ©s se sont tous bien dÃ©nouÃ©s. Elles font la vente de chaussures, dâ€™huile alimentaire, de vÃªtements, de Sounbala et de dâ€™atiÃ©kÃ¨ plus du poisson frais avec MariÃ©ou S. (qui a lâ€™enfant devant elle sur la photo) Avec son nouveau prÃªt, elle compte acheter, 100kg dâ€™atiÃ©kÃ¨ + 10kg de poissons. Elle sâ€™approvisionne au marchÃ© de Sikasso ville. Elle vend au marchÃ© de KAMALEN SIRAKORO et Ã domicile, au comptant et souvent Ã crÃ©dit Ã une clientÃ¨le composÃ©e dâ€™hommes et de femmes. Elle envisage rÃ©aliser un bÃ©nÃ©fice mensuel de 30.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisÃ©e pour lâ€™Ã©pargne et les besoins de la famille, lâ€™autre partie sera investie dans les activitÃ©s. Elle ambitionne avoir plus de capitaux pour mieux satisfaire sa clientÃ¨le et aider son mari Ã construire leur maison.
texts.en:
The group named Mougnoun is made up of married women with an average age of 37 years and each has 3 children. The majority of them live in polygamous families in Kamalen Sirakoro, a village in the Sikasso commune int eh thir administrative region of Mali. This group is a member of the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner). This is their fifth loan and with it they will meet their clients' demands. Their past credits have all been repaid. They sell shoes, cooking oil, clothing, a traditional condiment named Sounbala, and atiÃ©kÃ©, a granualted form of casava, as well as fresh fish with MariÃ©ou S. (the individual pictured here with a child). With this new loan she hopes to purchase 100kg of granulated casava root and 10kg of fish. She carries out her purchases in the village market in Sikasso. She makes her sales in the Kamalen Sirakoro markets and from her home, in cash and often on credit. Her clientele is made up of both men and women. She hopes to see monthly earnings of 30.500 francs, a part of which will be put away in savings, a part will be used to fill the family's needs, and a part will be reinvested back in the business. Her ambitions are to have larger capital funds to better satisfy her clients' demands and to help her husband build a house.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To purchase atiÃ©kÃ© and frensh fish.

loan.name: Akilimaya Group

texts.fr: Le groupe AKILIMAYA est constituÃ© de six femmes mariÃ©es ayant une moyenne dâ€™Ã¢ge de 29 ans, 4 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des familles polygames Ã KABOILA II, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3Ã¨me rÃ©gion administrative du Mali). Elles sont Ã leur quatriÃ¨me cycle en collaboration avec lâ€™institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientÃ¨le. Tous les prÃªts prÃ©cÃ©dents ont Ã©tÃ© bien remboursÃ©s. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce des produits alimentaires en gÃ©nÃ©rale tels que la vente dâ€™atiÃ©kÃ© avec MARIAM D.. MARIAM D., qui est un des membres du groupe, compte acheter avec son prÃªt 8 sacs dâ€™atiÃ©kÃ©. Elle sâ€™approvisionne au grand marchÃ© de la ville de Sikasso et souvent en CÃ´te dâ€™Ivoire. Elle revend au marchÃ© de Mancourani I et en famille Ã une clientÃ¨le composÃ©e de femmes et hommes, au comptant et souvent Ã crÃ©dit. Elle envisage rÃ©aliser un bÃ©nÃ©fice mensuel moyen de 40.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisÃ©e dans les dÃ©penses de la famille et lâ€™autre partie sera investie dans les activitÃ©s. Elle ambitionne augmenter son chiffre dâ€™affaire pour mieux satisfaire sa clientÃ¨le.
texts.en:
The group named Akilimaya is made up of six married women with an average age of 29. They each have four children and the majority of the members live in polygamous families in Kaboila II, a district of the village of Sikasso, third administrative region of Mali. They are on their fourth loan cycle with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner). They wish to fill the demands of their clientele. All their past loans have been successfully repaid. This group of women sell general food products, such as atiÃ©kÃ© (granulated casava) with Mariam D.. Mariam D. is a member of the group and with her loan she will purcahse 8 sacks of atiÃ©kÃ©. She makes her purchaes in the large market in the city of Sikasso, though she goes to Ivory Coast. She resells her merchandise in the Mancourani I market and to her family. Her clientele is made up of both men and money and she finalizes her sales in cash and often on credit. She hopes to earn 40.000 francs every month, of which a part will be put towards the family's expenses and another part will be reinvested back in to the business. Her ambitions are to increase her working capital to better satisfy her clientele.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To purchase atiÃ©kÃ©

loan.name: Fadimata

texts.fr: Fadimata D. est nÃ©e le 25 DÃ©cembre 1977 Ã Mopti (5Ã¨me rÃ©gion administrative du Mali), mariÃ©e et mÃ¨re de 5 enfants, elle rÃ©side avec son Ã©poux et leurs enfants Ã Sanoubougou I Extension, un des quartiers pÃ©ripheriques de la ville de Sikasso (troisiÃ¨me rÃ©gion administrative de la rÃ©publique du Mali). Issue dans une famille de pÃªcheur, Fadimata D. est nÃ©e dans cette activitÃ© de pÃªche et de vente de poissons. Elle achÃ¨te les poissons fumÃ©s Ã Mopti sur commande auprÃ¨s de ses parents pour les revendre au grand marchÃ© les jours de foire et le marchÃ© de leur localitÃ© les jours ouvrables oÃ¹ elle est beaucoup sollicitÃ©e de sa clientÃ¨le (composÃ©e essentiellement des des femmes de mÃ©nage et vendeuses de condiments alimentaires) pour la qualitÃ© de ses poissons. Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientÃ¨le de plus en plus croissante, elle dÃ©cida dâ€™intÃ©grer lâ€™institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elle a bÃ©nÃ©ficiÃ© dâ€™un premier prÃªt qui a Ã©tÃ© correctement remboursÃ©. Elle sollicite ce deuxiÃ¨me prÃªt, pour augmenter son fonds de commerce afin dâ€™acheter, 15 cartons de poissons fumÃ©s de diffÃ©rentes qualitÃ©s. Elle envisage rÃ©aliser un bÃ©nÃ©fice mensuel de 125 000 FCFA qui sera utilisÃ© essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dÃ©penses familiales et payer les intÃ©rÃªts de son prÃªt.
texts.en:
Fadimata D. was born December 25, 1977 in Mopti (fifth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). She is married and the mother of five children. She lives with her husband and their children in the Sanoubougou I extension, a neighborhood on the outskirts of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). Coming from a family of fishermen, Fadimata was born in the business of fishing and selling fish. She buys smoked fish on order in Mopti, from her parents, for resale at the big market on fair days. On regular workdays, she sells the smoked fish at the local market where she is in high demand by her customers (consisting mostly of housewives and condiment vendors) for the quality of her product. In order to better serve a steadily increasing customer base, she decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution where she received a first loan that was repaid without incident. She is seeking a second loan to expand her business. She plans to buy 15 cartons of smoked fish of varying grades. She expects to achieve a monthly profit of 125,000 FCFA to be used primarily to increase her working capital, help with the family expenses, and pay the interest on the loan.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Buy smoked fish

loan.name: Germaine

texts.fr:
Madame GERMAINE D. est une femme de 52 ans. Elle est veuve et mÃ¨re de 06 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de NGASCOP depuis 13 ans. Elle a 25 fois reÃ§u de crÃ©dit et a toujours remboursÃ© sans difficultÃ©.
Elle fait de l'embouche bovine. Elle pratique cette activitÃ© depuis plus d'une dÃ©cennie
Avec son nouveau crÃ©dit il se permettra d'acheter 05 bÅ“ufs qu'elle va emboucher pendant au moins 5 mois avant de les revendre au niveau des marchÃ©s hebdomadaires de leurs localitÃ©s.
Son objectif est de subvenir Ã ses besoins personnels et de prendre en charge les besoins de la famille.
texts.en:
Germaine D. is a 52 year old woman. She is a widow and teh mother of 6 children. She has been a member of the community bank NGASCOP (Kiva Field Partner) for the past 13 years. She has had 25 past loans and they have all been repaid without difficulty. She is a cattle farmer, a business she has kept for more than 10 years. With this loan she will purchase 5 calves that she will raise for at least 5 months and then resell them in the weekly market fairs in the region. Her goal is to attend to her personal needs and to provide for the needs of her family.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To purchase 5 calves.

loan.name: Fatoumata YÃ©hia

texts.fr: Madame Fatoumata YÃ©hia Y. est Ã¢gÃ©e de 46 ans et mÃ¨re dâ€™une fille. Elle rÃ©side avec son Ã©poux Ã Bougoula-Ville Sikasso ( troisiÃ¨me rÃ©gion administrative de la rÃ©publique du Mali). Nâ€™ayant pas eu la chance dâ€™avancer Ã lâ€™Ã©cole pour des raisons sociales, elle sâ€™est initiÃ©e aux activitÃ©s dâ€™achat et de vente de lait en poudre, de moquettes, de couvre-lits, de cache-murs et autres divers articles, depuis plus de dix ans. Elle passe les commandes de ses marchandises Ã Gao (7Ã¨me rÃ©gion administrative du Mali) en provenance dâ€™AlgÃ©rie dans le Maghreb quâ€™elle revend de faÃ§on ambulante dans les diffÃ©rentes structures professionnelles de la ville. Elle est beaucoup sollicitÃ©e surtout de sa clientÃ¨le pour la qualitÃ© de ses produits. Elle vend ses marchandises au comptant et Ã crÃ©dit. Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientÃ¨le de plus en plus croissante, elle dÃ©cida dâ€™intÃ©grer lâ€™institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ une annÃ©e. Elle est Ã son deuxiÃ¨me prÃªt qui lui permettra dâ€™acquÃ©rir, 13 cartons de laits en poudre, 10 moquettes de diffÃ©rentes dimensions, 4 couvre-lits, 6 paires de cache-murs, 5 carton de Couscous arabe, etc. Elle envisage rÃ©aliser avec ce prÃªt un bÃ©nÃ©fice mensuel de 200 000 FCFA qui sera utilisÃ© essentiellement pour contribuer aux dÃ©penses familiales, payer les intÃ©rÃªts de son prÃªt et investir le reste dans son activitÃ©.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatoumata Yehia Y. is 46 years old and mother to one daughter. She lives with her husband in the village of Bougoula in Sikasso, third administrative region in the Republic of Mali. For socio-economic reasons she was not able to attend school so she started a business, buying and selling powdered milk, thick wool fabrics, bed spreads, and drapes and various other articles. She has had this business for ten years. She fills her orders for merchandise in Gao (the seventh administrative region in Mali) but the merchandise comes from Maghreb, Algeria. She resells her merchandise door to door and to businesses in her village. Given the high quality of the products she sells she is always sought out by her clientele. She finalizes her sales in cash and on credit. With the goal of better satisfying her ever growing client base she approached the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso last year. This will be her second loan and it will be used to purchase 13 cartons of powdered milk, 10 pieces of wool fabric of different sizes, 4 bed spreads, 6 pairs of curtains, 5 cartons of couscous, etc. She foresees earning a monthly income of 200.000 francs, part of which will used towards the family's expenses, part to pay off the loan, and part will be reinvested into the business.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To purchase various merchandise.

loan.name: Malik

texts.fr: Monsieur Malik Mâ€™BÃ” Ã¢gÃ© de 37 ans, mariÃ©, pÃ¨re de quatre enfants il habite avec sa famille Ã Sanoubougou I-Sikasso (troisiÃ¨me rÃ©gion administrative de la rÃ©publique du Mali) . Il exerce lâ€™activitÃ© dâ€™achat et de vente PrÃªt Ã Porter depuis environ quatre ans aprÃ¨s avoir menÃ© plusieurs activitÃ©s sans succÃ¨s. Vu lâ€™augmentation de sa clientÃ¨le et que ses ressources propres ne pouvant satisfaire les attentes de cette clientÃ¨le, il jugea utile de venir auprÃ¨s de lâ€™institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso pour lui solliciter ce premier prÃªt individuel qui lui permettra dâ€™acheter, 10 chemises de diffÃ©rentes qualitÃ©s, 15 pantalons de qualitÃ©s diffÃ©rentes, 20 paires de chaussure de diffÃ©rentes qualitÃ©s (Soulier, Ferardine, etc.), 4 complets de veste, 10 Tee-Shirt, etc. Il sâ€™approvisionne Ã Bamako afin de les revendre dans sa boutique situÃ©e en pleine cÅ“ur de la gare routiÃ¨re de Sikasso Ã une clientÃ¨le composÃ©e essentiellement de voyageurs et transporteurs. Il envisage rÃ©aliser avec ce premier crÃ©dit un bÃ©nÃ©fice mensuel moyen de 120 000 FCFA qui permettra dâ€™augmenter son fonds de commerce mais Ã©galement dâ€™honorer ses engagements Ã lâ€™Ã©gard de Soro Yiriwaso et couvrir dâ€™autres dÃ©penses familles.
texts.en:
Mr. Malik Mâ€™BÃ´ is 37 years old, married and the father of four children. He lives with his family in Sanabougou I, Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). He has been a retailer of ready-to-wear clothing for the past four years, after unsuccessfully trying his hand at different activities. Given the increasing number of customers and his inability to meet their expectations using his own resources, he found it useful to approach the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to request a first personal loan. The loan will enable him to buy clothes of varying quality: 10 shirts, 15 slacks, 20 pairs of shoes (Soulier and Ferardine brands), 4 vests, 10 T-shirts, etc. He resupplies in Bamako and resells his products in his shop located at the very centre of the Sikasso bus station, mainly to a customer base of travellers and drivers. With this first loan he hopes to reach average monthly earnings of 120,000 FCFA. This will enable him to increase his working capital but also honour his commitments to Soro Yiriwaso and cover other family expenses.

Translated from French by RenÃ© McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To buy clothing (shirts, slacks, T-shirts, shoes, etc.)

loan.name: JiguisÃ¨mÃ¨ Group

texts.fr: Les quatre femmes du groupe JiguisÃ¨mÃ¨ (sont toutes mariÃ©es) avec une moyenne dâ€™Ã¢ge de 33 ans, 4 enfants, vivent dans des familles monogames Ã Ouayerma II un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3Ã¨me rÃ©gion administrative du Mali). Elles collaborent avec lâ€™institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientÃ¨le et sont Ã leur cinquiÃ¨me prÃªt, tous les passÃ©s se sont bien dÃ©nouÃ©s. Elles mÃ¨nent diverses activitÃ©s qui sont entre autres la vente de friperie, de fruits et lÃ©gumes et de tasses avec AWA K.. Avec son prÃªt, elle compte acheter, 4 douzaines de tasses. Elle sâ€™approvisionne au grand marchÃ© de Sikasso ville. Les tasses sont vendues au marchÃ© de Ouayerma et souvent de faÃ§on ambulante dans les familles Ã une clientÃ¨le composÃ©e dâ€™hommes et de femmes et la plupart au comptant. Elles envisagent rÃ©aliser chacune un bÃ©nÃ©fice mensuel moyen de 35.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisÃ©e pour les besoins de la famille et lâ€™autre partie sera investie dans les activitÃ©s. Elle ambitionne dâ€™aider son mari Ã construire leur maison Ã usage dâ€™habitation.
texts.en:
The four women of the JiguisÃ¨mÃ¨ group are married and, on average, are 33 years old with 4 children. They live in monogamous families in Ouayerma II, one of the neighborhoods of the city of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali). They collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy their customersâ€™ needs. They are on their fifth loan; all previous loans have been fully repaid. They run various businesses, including selling second-hand clothing and fruits and vegetables. AWA K. sells basins. With her loan, she plans to buy 4 dozen basins. She gets her stock at the large market in Sikasso. The basins are sold at the Ouayerma market and often door-to-door or from the home to a clientele composed of men and women and mostly in cash. They each expect to make an average monthly profit of 35,000 CFA of which a part will be used for the familyâ€™s needs and the remainder will be invested in the businesses. She hopes to help her husband to build a house in which to live.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To buy basins

loan.name: Soro Yiriwa Group

texts.fr: Les six femmes du groupe Soro Yiriwa (sont toutes mariÃ©es) avec une moyenne dâ€™Ã¢ge de 38 ans et en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles monogames Ã Ouayerma II un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3Ã¨me rÃ©gion administrative du Mali). Elles collaborent avec lâ€™institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientÃ¨le et sont Ã leur cinquiÃ¨me prÃªt. Tous les prÃªts passÃ©s se sont bien dÃ©nouÃ©s. Elles vendent divers produits qui sont entre autres des oranges avec MARIAM C.. Avec son nouveau prÃªt, elle compte acheter, 3 chargements de charrette en oranges. Elle sâ€™approvisionne dans les villages avoisinants de SIKASSO et au grand marchÃ© de MÃ©dine (Sikasso ville). Les oranges sont vendues au marchÃ© de Ouayerma et Ã domicile Ã une clientÃ¨le composÃ©e dâ€™hommes et de femmes et la plupart au comptant. Elle envisage rÃ©aliser chacune un bÃ©nÃ©fice mensuel moyen de 22.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisÃ©e pour les besoins de la famille et lâ€™autre partie sera mise en Ã©pargne. Elle ambitionne avoir son propre magasin au marchÃ© afin de mieux satisfaire sa clientÃ¨le.
texts.en:
The six women of the Soro Yiriwa group are all married and average 38 years of age with an average of four children each. The majority of them live in monogamous families in Ouayerma II, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). They are working the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, in order to satisfy their customers' needs, and they are on their fifth loan. All the previous loans have been repaid in full. They sell various products, including oranges, which Mariam C. sells. With her new loan, she is planning to buy three barrow loads of oranges. She gets her supplies in Sikasso's neighboring villages and at the large market in MÃ©dine (Sikasso town). The oranges are sold at the market in Ouayerma and at home to a customer base made up of men and women, mostly for cash. She is expecting to make an average monthly profit of 22,500FCFA, of which part will be used for family needs and the rest saved. Her ambition is to have her own shop in the market in order to better satisfy her customers.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchase of fruits

loan.name: Tileneya Group

texts.fr: Les quatre femmes du groupe Tileneya (sont toutes mariÃ©es) avec une moyenne dâ€™Ã¢ge de 28 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles monogames Ã Ouayerma 1 un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3Ã¨me rÃ©gion administrative du Mali). Elles sont Ã leur cinquiÃ¨me collaboration avec lâ€™institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientÃ¨le. Les prÃªts passÃ©s se sont tous bien dÃ©nouÃ©s. Elles mÃ¨nent diverses activitÃ©s qui sont entre autres la vente de fruits et lÃ©gumes, de poissons, du bois de chauffe, du charbon e bois et des condiments alimentaires avec KADI B.. Avec son nouveau prÃªt, elle compte acheter, 5 paniers de choux, 3 sacs de jakatou, 5 paniers de tomates fraiches, 10 sacs dâ€™oignons et 5 sacs dâ€˜Ã©pices. Elle sâ€™approvisionne au grand marchÃ© de Sikasso et dans les localitÃ©s avoisinantes. Les produits sont vendus au marchÃ© et dans la famille ou sur commande Ã une clientÃ¨le composÃ©e essentiellement de femmes et la plupart au comptant. Elle envisage rÃ©aliser chacune un bÃ©nÃ©fice mensuel moyen de 35.000 FCFA dont une partie sera investie dans les activitÃ©s et lâ€™autre partie en Ã©pargne. Elle ambitionne dâ€™acheter un terrain Ã usage dâ€™habitation.
texts.en:
The four women in the Tileneya group, who are all married, average 28 years of age with three children. They live in monogamous families in Ouayerma 1, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). They are on their fifth loan from the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with the goal of satisfying their customers' needs. The previous loans have all been repaid in full. They have various activities, which include the sale of fruit and vegetables, fish, firewood, charcoal and wood, and condiments; Kadi B. sells the latter. With her new loan she is planning to buy five baskets of cabbages, three sacks of "jakatou" (a vegetable belonging to the eggplant family), five baskets of fresh tomatoes, ten sacks of onions and five sacks of spices. She gets her supplies at the large market in Sikasso and in neighboring towns. The products are sold at the market and within the family or on order, to a customer base made up essentially of women, and mainly for cash. She is expecting to make an average monthly profit of 35,000FCFA, of which part will be invested in the business and part saved. Her ambition is to buy a piece of land to live on.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchase of condiments

loan.name: Jekafo Group

texts.fr: Les cinq membres du groupe Jekafo sont des femmes mariÃ©es avec une moyenne dâ€™Ã¢ge de 39 ans et en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles monogames Ã Hamdallaye, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, (3Ã¨me rÃ©gion administrative du Mali). Elles sont Ã leur troisiÃ¨me prÃªt en collaboration avec lâ€™institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientÃ¨le. Les prÃªts antÃ©rieurs ont Ã©tÃ© bien remboursÃ©s. Elles font la vente dâ€˜articles divers tels la friperie avec Aminata S.. Avec son nouveau prÃªt, Aminata S. compte acheter 7 balles de friperie. Elles sâ€™approvisionne Ã Bamako et au grand marchÃ© de Sikasso. Elles vend Ã Sikasso ville ( Ã domicile, dans les marchÃ©s et dans les quartiers de faÃ§on ambulante), au comptant, souvent Ã crÃ©dit avec une clientÃ¨le composÃ©e dâ€™hommes et de femmes. Elle envisage rÃ©aliser un bÃ©nÃ©fice mensuel moyen de 28.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisÃ©e pour lâ€™Ã©pargne et les besoins de la famille, lâ€™autre partie sera investie dans les activitÃ©s. Elle ambitionne avoir plus de capitaux pour mieux satisfaire sa clientÃ¨le et pouvoir amÃ©nager son point de vente.
texts.en:
The five members of the Jekafo group are married women, who average 39 years of age with an average of three children. They live in monogamous families in Hamdallaye, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). They are on their third loan from the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with the goal of satisfying their customers' needs. The previous loans have been repaid in full. They sell a variety of articles, such as second-hand clothing, sold by Aminata S.. With her new loan, Aminata S. is planning on buying seven bales of second-hand clothes. She gets her supplies in Bamako and at the large market in Sikasso. She sells her goods in Sikasso town (at home, in markets and wandering around the various neighborhoods), for cash, but often on credit to a customer base made up of men and women. She is expecting to make an average monthly profit of 28,500FCFA, of which part will be used for savings and family needs, while the rest is invested in the business. Her ambition is to have more capital in order to better satisfy her customers and to do up her sales outlet.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To buy second-hand clothing

loan.name: Believe In God Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the â€œBelieve In God" Group. They are microentrepreneurs based in Makeni city, in Northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of 1,400,000 leones each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living.
The leader of this group is Mariatu K., who is pictured on the left. Mariatu is age 35 and was born in a place called Sanda. She is married with four children. Her husband is a teacher and her children are attending schools: two in primary school, one in secondary school and the other is still not of school-going age. For ten years now, Mariatu has been selling clothes for babies. She will use her share of this loan to buy more clothes to add to her business.

loan.use: To buy more baby clothes

loan.name: Mohamedi

texts.fr: NÃ© le 12 Novembre 1988 Ã Sikasso ville, Monsieur Mohamedi T. est cÃ©libataire sans enfant rÃ©sidant dans une grande famille traditionnelle Ã KaboÃ¯la II-Sikasso (troisiÃ¨me rÃ©gion administrative de la rÃ©publique du Mali). Nâ€™ayant pas la chance dâ€™avancer aux Ã©tudes, il sâ€™est initiÃ© il y a dix ans Ã cette activitÃ© dâ€™achat-vente de fruits et lÃ©gumes (pomme de terre, orange, melon, patate, citron,etc.). Avec une telle expÃ©rience dans ce domaine, il jouit dâ€™une forte rÃ©putation et reÃ§oit beaucoup de commandes au niveau de Bamako, mais les ressources nÃ©cessaires pour satisfaire ces besoins fait dÃ©faut. Ainsi, il intÃ©gra Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est Ã son premier prÃªt, qui lui permettra dâ€™augmenter son fonds de commerce pour enfin rÃ©pondre aux attentes de ses clients. Ce premier prÃªt lui permettra dâ€™acheter dans les localitÃ©s environnantes de Sikasso auprÃ¨s des producteurs, 10 sacs de pomme de terre, 10 sacs dâ€™orange, 15 sacs de citron, 20 sacs de patate, etc. Ses ventes sont faites en gros et en dÃ©tail Ã une clientÃ¨le composÃ©e de toutes les couches sociales mais surtout de restaurateurs. Avec ce premier prÃªt, il envisage rÃ©aliser un bÃ©nÃ©fice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisÃ© pour rÃ©soudre lâ€™essentielle de ses dÃ©penses, celles de sa famille et investir le reste dans son activitÃ©.
texts.en:
Born on November 12, 1988 in the town of Sikasso, Mr. Mohamedi T. is single, without children, and lives in a traditional extended family in Kaboila-II-Sikasso (the third administrative region of Mali). Not having had a chance to progress in his studies, about ten years ago he launched a business purchasing and reselling fruits and vegetables (potatoes, oranges, melons, sweet potatoes, lemons etc). With such a long experience, he enjoys a good reputation in the business and receives many orders in Bamako; however, he lacks the necessary resources to meet his customersâ€™ expectations. This is why he joined Soro Yiriwaso, and is now on his first loan. The loan would allow him to expend his working capital in order to better respond to customer demand. This first loan will allow him to purchase from farmers in the Sikasso region 10 bags of potatoes, 10 bags of oranges, 15 bags of lemons, 20 bags of sweet potatoes etc. He sells wholesale and retail to customers from all social layers, but most of all to restaurant owners. With this first loan, he plans to achieve a monthly income of 100,000 West African Francs, which will be used to cover his essential needs as well as the needs of his family, with the rest reinvested in the business.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchasing fruits and vegetables (potatoes, oranges, lemons, sweet potatoes, etc).

loan.name: Atamu Group

texts.en: Pictured here are members of the Atamu Group. They are microentrepreneurs based in Makeni city, Northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of 1,000,000 leones each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living. The leader of this group is Kadiatu S., pictured on the left. Kadiatu is age 40 and was born in Makeni. She is married with five children. Her husband is a businessman and her children are attending primary and secondary schools. For many years now, Kadiatu has been selling market food: rice, palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), Maggi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), groundnuts, pepper, etc. With this loan, she will expand her business by buying more stock wholesale to add to her current stock. Also included in the photo is Maseray Kamara, a former group member.

loan.use: To buy rice, palm oil, Maggi, groundnuts, pepper, etc., wholesale

loan.name: DjiguissÃ¨mÃ¨ Group

texts.fr: Les femmes du groupe DjiguissÃ¨mÃ¨ sont toutes mariÃ©es. Elles ont en moyenne 48 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles Ã©largies dans le village de TÃ¨nÃ¨ relevant de SAN(quatriÃ¨me rÃ©gion administrative de la rÃ©publique du Mali). Ces femmes se sont connues Ã travers des liens de voisinage, de parentÃ© et font essentiellement de la restauration et lâ€™achat vente de cÃ©rÃ©ales. AprÃ¨s avoir correctement remboursÃ©s les 3 prÃªts prÃ©cÃ©dents, les femmes du groupe sont Ã leur 4 prÃªt solidaire. KADIA T., la prÃ©sidente du groupe, compte utiliser ce nouveau prÃªt pour acheter, 10 sacs de cÃ©rÃ©ales (haricot mil, maÃ¯s, riz) et une importante quantitÃ© dâ€™ingrÃ©dients pour la restauration. Elle sâ€™approvisionne essentiellement sur place auprÃ¨s des producteurs de cÃ©rÃ©ales et grossistes pour les ingrÃ©dients rentrant dans la restauration au marchÃ© hebdomadaire de TÃ¨nÃ¨ et effectue sa vente sur place au marchÃ© de TÃ¨nÃ¨ et Ã domicile, au comptant en dÃ©tail et Ã crÃ©dit, Ã une clientÃ¨le composÃ©e de femmes et dâ€™hommes. Elle envisage rÃ©aliser un bÃ©nÃ©fice moyen mensuel de 20.000 FCFA qui servira Ã Ã©toffer son fonds de commerce et subvenir aux dÃ©penses ayant trait Ã la nourriture, Ã la scolaritÃ© des enfants et Ã la santÃ©. Les autres membres espÃ¨rent rÃ©aliser un bÃ©nÃ©fice mensuel de 18.000 FCFA chacune.
texts.en:
The members of the DijugissÃ¨mÃ¨ group are all married women who are on the average 48 years old, with four children. They live in traditional extended families in the village of TÃ¨nÃ¨ (San Prefecture, the 4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women know each other as neighbors and friends; their main line of business is cooking food for sale and selling cereals. After having duly repaid 3 previous loans, they are now on their 4th solidarity loan. Kadia Threa, the groupâ€™s leader, plans to use this new loan to purchase ten bags of cereals (beans, millet, corn, and rice) and an ample supply of ingredients for cooking. She purchases her stock locally from cereal farmers as well as, in case of other ingredients, from wholesalers, at the weekly market in TÃ¨nÃ¨. She sells at the local market of TÃ¨nÃ¨ and out of her home, retail, for cash and on credit, to a customer base composed of both men and women. She anticipates earning an average monthly income of 20,000 West African Francs, which will bolster her business capital and allow her to cover expenses related to food, healthcare, and her childrenâ€™s schooling. Other members hope to achieve a monthly income of 18,000 West African Francs each.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchasing food products

loan.name: Fente Allah BÃ´ Group

texts.fr: Les femmes du groupe Fente Allah bÃ´ sont toutes mariÃ©es. Elles ont en moyenne 39 ans, 8 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles Ã©largies dans le village de TÃ¨nÃ¨ relevant de la sous-prÃ©fecture de TÃ¨nÃ¨, prÃ©fecture de SAN, (quatriÃ¨me rÃ©gion administrative de la rÃ©publique du Mali). Ces femmes se sont connues Ã travers des liens de voisinage, de parentÃ© et font essentiellement lâ€™achat vente de tissus, de pagnes wax, de bijoux et des produits cosmÃ©tiques. AprÃ¨s avoir correctement remboursÃ©s les 4 prÃªts prÃ©cÃ©dents, les femmes du groupe sont Ã leur 5 prÃªt solidaire. BINTOU D. utilisera son nouveau prÃªt pour acheter 2 balles de pagnes wax, 3 douzaines de bijoux et une importante quantitÃ© de produits cosmÃ©tiques. Elle sâ€™approvisionne essentiellement Ã Bamako et au Burkina Faso avec les grossistes pour revendre au marchÃ© hebdomadaire de TÃ¨nÃ¨, dans les foires hebdomadaires environnantes et Ã domicile, au comptant en dÃ©tail et Ã crÃ©dit, Ã une clientÃ¨le composÃ©e de femmes et dâ€™hommes. Tandis que les autres membres du groupe comptent avoir 26.000FCFA, BINTOU D. envisage rÃ©aliser un bÃ©nÃ©fice moyen mensuel de 29.000 FCFA qui servira Ã Ã©toffer son fonds de commerce et subvenir aux dÃ©penses de nourriture, de scolaritÃ© et de santÃ©.
texts.en:
The women of the Fente Allah bÃ´ group are all married. On average, they are 39 years old, have 8 children and all live in extended traditional families in the village of TÃ¨nÃ¨ in the sub-prefecture of TÃ¨nÃ¨, prefecture of SAN (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women met each other through neighborhood connections and family ties. They mainly buy and sell fabric, wax â€œpagnesâ€ (traditional brightly-colored fabric), jewelry and cosmetics. After having repaid in full the 4 previous loans, the women of the group are on their fifth solidarity loan. BINTOU D. will use her new loan to buy 2 bolts of wax â€œpagnesâ€, 3 dozen jewelry pieces and a large quantity of cosmetics. She gets her supplies mainly in Bamako and in Burkina Faso from wholesalers. She sells them at the weekly market in TÃ¨nÃ¨, in weekly market fairs nearby and door-to-door. Cash or credit for retail sales is accepted from a customer base composed of women and men. While the other members of the group expect to earn 26,000 CFA Francs, BINTOU D. envisions making an average monthly profit of 29,000 CFA Francs that she will use to expand her business and provide for food, school and health expenses.

Translated from French by Marie-Elodie Bazy, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To buy various goods

loan.name: Sabenty Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the Sabenty Group. They are microentrepreneurs residing in the northern city of Makeni. They are seeking a loan of 800,000 leones each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more sales and better profit and improve their standard of living.
The leader of this group is Zainab K.. Thirty-six-year-old Zainab was born in Makeni. She is married with four children. Her husband is a driver and her children are attending schools: one in primary school, two in secondary school and the youngest is not of school-going age. Zainab has been selling market food â€“ rice, palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), etc. â€“ for a very long time now. Zainab also sells slippers (flip-flops). With the help of this loan, Zainab will buy market food and slippers in large quantity to add to her business.

loan.use: To buy market food and slippers in large quantity

loan.name: Batoma

texts.fr: Madame Batoma SingarÃ© est Ã¢gÃ©e de 29 ans, mariÃ©e et mÃ¨re de 4 enfants.
